repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: Justification: I want to be able to toggle some LSPs on/off (see https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/33702), and I'd like to be able to do that without having to reach into `lsp.lua` internals like `lsp._enabled_configs`.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
--- Checks if the given LSP config is enabled or not.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -594,6 +594,14 @@ function lsp.enable(name, enable)
     })
 end
 
+--- Checks if the given LSP is enabled or not.

@@ -594,6 +594,14 @@ function lsp.enable(name, enable)
     })
 end
 
+--- Checks if the given LSP is enabled or not.
+---
+--- @param name string Name of the client

comment_data.body: @lewis6991 will know better but I think that we should also check `lsp.config._configs['*']` here (in case the LSP server was configured with `vim.lsp.config('*', ...)`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -594,6 +594,14 @@ function lsp.enable(name, enable)
     })
 end
 
+--- Checks if the given LSP config is enabled or not.
+---
+--- @param name string Config name
+--- @return boolean
+function lsp.is_enabled(name)
+  return lsp._enabled_configs[name] ~= nil

comment_data.body: `*` is a weird case. I don't think we need to check for it here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -594,6 +594,14 @@ function lsp.enable(name, enable)
     })
 end
 
+--- Checks if the given LSP config is enabled or not.
+---
+--- @param name string Config name
+--- @return boolean
+function lsp.is_enabled(name)
+  return lsp._enabled_configs[name] ~= nil

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
--- Checks if the given LSP config is enabled (globally, not per-buffer).
---
--- Note: "configs" are _used by_ "clients", which attach to buffers.
--- Use |vim.lsp.get_clients()| to check active LSP clients for a given buffer.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -594,6 +594,14 @@ function lsp.enable(name, enable)
     })
 end
 
+--- Checks if the given LSP config is enabled or not.

comment_data.body: Done. Just wondering: this phrasing sort of implies that you can enable/disable a LSP config per buffer. Is that possible?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -594,6 +594,14 @@ function lsp.enable(name, enable)
     })
 end
 
+--- Checks if the given LSP config is enabled or not.

comment_data.body: No, the phrasing is intended to avoid confusion by being explicit. Clients are enabled per-buffer, and it's likely that users will get that confused with configs, which are (roughly) global.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -594,6 +594,14 @@ function lsp.enable(name, enable)
     })
 end
 
+--- Checks if the given LSP config is enabled or not.

comment_regular_data.body:
I'm like warm about this, but don't strongly object.

Functions like this will become irrelevant if we ever decide to create a `'lsp'` buffer option, which would probably change the dynamics of how people think about this subject.

> Functions like this will become irrelevant if we ever decide to create a `'lsp'` buffer option, which would probably change the dynamics of how people think about this subject.

good point. though they might still be relevant if they have advanced filters like `vim.diagnostic.is_enabled()` .

unfortunately, it may be awhile before we have "dict options", which are likely needed for this and treesitter.
My thought was that an `lsp` option could just be a comma separated string of server names and can be appended to in `FileType` autocmds.
This is somewhat redundant with `vim.lsp.config['foo']`, but that forces loading/resolving the config, so I guess `is_enabled` is needed.

repo.name: neovim

title: feat(lsp): vim.lsp.is_enabled()
